description: Broke Islamic State Jihadi Mohammad Ali Baryalei begged his friend Omarjan Azari to send money to the Middle East, a Sydney court has heard.
title: Jihadi Mohammad Ali Baryalei asked Omarjan Azari for money
title_page: Jihadi Mohammad Ali Baryalei asked Omarjan Azari for money | Daily Mail Online
text:
When an overseas Islamic State member called Omarjan Azari about a money transfer in 2014, the Sydney man was dealing with 'a bit of turmoil,' a court has heard.
A mate he previously relied on to help transfer the money had been approached by ASIO and things were getting 'heated up', Azari allegedly said during a phone conversation with Mohammad Ali Baryalei.
'Every brother I ask, yeah, like they refuse. They didn't want to do it,' he said.
But Azari insisted he would find someone and 'worst case scenario I'll probably just use a woman to do it'.
Scroll down for video
Broke Islamic State Jihadi Mohammad Ali Baryalei (pictured) begged his friend Omarjan Azari to send money to the Middle East, a Sydney court has heard
Azari (pictured) allegedly told Baryalei he had trouble finding someone to transfer the money because they have been approached by ASIO
Almost three years later, 24-year-old Azari is on trial in the NSW Supreme Court on terror charges and Baryalei, who left Australia in 2013, is believed to be dead.
Azari pleaded guilty on Monday to making funds available to a terrorist organisation, but has pleaded not guilty to another charge of doing an act to prepare or plan for a terrorist act.
The jury on Wednesday heard recordings of 2014 phone conversations in Arabic, Dari and English allegedly involving Afghan-born Azari.
In one, Baryalei told Azari about three 'brothers' who were going to 'do a martyrdom operation', and Azari spoke about an acquaintance who was 'involved in something big in the airport', according to a translated transcript.
'He said apparently that he's moving to the place where they - they're gonna attack the airport,' he said.
The Crown is alleging that in another phone conversation with Baryalei, Azari prepared or planned for a terrorist act.
Almost three years later, 24-year-old Azari (right) is on trial in the NSW Supreme Court on terror charges and Baryalei, who left Australia in 2013, is believed to be dead
The jury heard on Monday that Baryalei (pictured) told Azari to 'terminate' at least five people a month, including a 'random unbeliever'
The jury heard on Monday that Baryalei told Azari to 'terminate' at least five people a month, including a 'random unbeliever.'
Baryalei said backpackers would make good targets because it would attract worldwide media attention, the court heard.
But defence barrister John Stratton SC said Azari, who had two relatives in Syria under the authority of Baryalei, was trying to find a way to abandon the plan and never agreed to it.
'What the accused was attempting to do was to find excuses to put off Mr Baryalei,' Mr Stratton said during his opening address.
The trial continues.
